qas.question: Have there been any changes to restrictions placed on the communications networks in Burma ?

answers.text: Restrictions on media censorship were significantly eased in August 2012

qas.question: If communications restrictions have changed how so?

answers.text: The most significant change has come in the form that media organisations will no longer have to submit their content to a censorship board before publication.

qas.question: What is the name of the newspaper that was banished from Burma?
What is required of commentators before publishing or airing content ?

answers.text: journalists "are required to follow 16 guidelines towards protecting the three national causes

qas.question: What did demonstrators wear during the media rally?

answers.text: wore shirts demanding that the government "Stop Killing the Press.

context: <a0_0>Restrictions on media censorship were significantly eased in August 2012<a0_0/> following demonstrations by hundreds of protesters who <a4_0>wore shirts demanding that the government "Stop Killing the Press.<a4_0/>" <a1_0>The most significant change has come in the form that media organisations will no longer have to submit their content to a censorship board before publication.<a1_0/> However, as explained by one editorial in the exiled press <a2_0>The Irrawaddy<a2_0/>, this new "freedom" has caused some Burmese journalists to simply see the new law as an attempt to create an environment of self-censorship as <a3_0>journalists "are required to follow 16 guidelines towards protecting the three national causes<a3_0/> — non-disintegration of the Union, non-disintegration of national solidarity, perpetuation of sovereignty — and "journalistic ethics" to ensure their stories are accurate and do not jeopardise national security." In July 2014 five journalists were sentenced to 10 years in jail after publishing a report saying the country was planning to build a new chemical weapons plant. Journalists described the jailings as a blow to the recently-won news media freedoms that had followed five decades of censorship and persecution.
